Gunjan Saxena, one of the first women to fly in a combat zone, is an Indian Air Force pilot.
The film 'Gunjan Saxena: The Kargil Girl' was extensively filmed across Lucknow.
Gunjan Saxena's proud parents, Anup and Kirti, were planning to send her to high school.
Gunjan, however wants to drop out of high school to become a pilot.
Young Gunjan Saxena's older brother Anshuman doesn't let her look out of the airplane window in a flight.
A kind air hostess tends to the problem and takes Gunjan to the cockpit.
The story of 'Gunjan Saxena: The Kargil Girl' begins with young Gunjan Saxena in a flight along with her older brother, Anshuman, in 1984.
Gunjan Saxena is congratulated for her academic excellence.

Gunjan's acceptance into the Indian Air Force provides her with an opportunity to pursue her dream, despite initial reservations from family members and a male colleague. However, she faces additional challenges due to her height and gender during training.
Anup fully supports Gunjan's decision to pursue her dream of joining the Indian Air Force, encouraging her when others doubt her.
Kirti expresses pride in her sister Gunjan's acceptance into the Indian Air Force, highlighting her own family members' differing opinions.
Anshuman initially disapproves of Gunjan joining the Indian Air Force due to its male-dominated nature, but she ignores his reservations and continues with her training.

commenced in February 2019, with the film being extensively shot at Lucknow.
The film was commenced in Lucknow in February 2019.
The film's shooting, despite being continued for three months, came to halt in May 2019 citing the bad weather, but later resumed.
The team planned to shoot few scenes at London on July.
The team planned to change the location to Georgia.
The team planned to shoot some sequences in a town called Kazbegi, which is a mountainous area set over 5700 feet above sea level.
Both Janhvi Kapoor and Angad Bedi have shot the sequences for maintaining fitness for their roles, being accompanied by coach Brinston Miranda.
Shooting of the film was wrapped up on 29 December 2019.
The film's music was composed by Amit Trivedi while lyrics were written by Kausar Munir.

Retired Wing Commander Namrita Chandi also said that it was not Gunjan, but Sreevidya Rajan who was the first lady pilot who flew to Kargil.
Retired Wing Commander Namrita Chandi stated that it was not Gunjan, but Sreevidya Rajan who was the first lady pilot to fly to Kargil. Therefore, credit is being wrongly taken away by Gunjan.
Rajan stated that she had never claimed credit due to her strong belief in gender equality.
Authorities in the Indian Air Force (IAF) wrote a letter to the Central Board of Film Certification over the alleged 'undue negative portrayal' of the IAF personnel.

Pointing out that IAF was the first branch of Indian Armed Forces to recruit female officers in the force, the IAF said that they have a gender-neutral workforce and do not propagate gender biases in their service.
IAF claimed that Johar had agreed to represent it with authenticity and 'make all efforts to ensure that the film helps inspire the next generation of IAF Officers.'
Certain scenes and dialogues in the film and its trailer were shown to have projected the IAF in bad light.
Wing Commander Namrita Chandi also remarked that the makers had exaggerated the gender conflict.
Many ex-army officers expressed similar concerns.
She also stated that heroic acts may have been shown as part of cinematic licence.
During a media interaction arranged by the IAF towards the end of the Kargil conflict, Saxena's name was projected as the first woman to fly for the IAF in a combat zone.
wing commander deepa nailwal also stated the same regarding the gender conflict.
later, the defense ministry also raised concerns over the gender disparity shown in the film regarding the gender conflict.
defending the portrayal of gender bias in the film, saxena clarified that the 'bias is not at an organizational level'.

since the bias is not at an organizational level, the experiences of different woman officers would be different. To deny it completely speaks of a feudal mindset and undermines the grit of women officers'.

The Hindustan Times praised the film Gunjan Saxena: The Kargil Girl as a refreshing change of pace for war films in India, which have forever been defined by whatever JP Dutta does. It further mentioned that this film would touch a chord especially with family audience.
